;马来西亚旅游、艺术及文化部长张景星声称他必须亲自介入周四，一名中国媒体公司的员工从深圳抵达吉隆坡国际机场 (KLIA)，移民官员将她拦住后，为她提供帮助。

;

;该女子声称，尽管她的旅行证件在根据命令，她被移民官员拒绝入境。

;

;她声称，如果她想获准入境，就被要求支付数千林吉特。

;

;该女子抵达马来西亚时带着

;

;据悉，虽然她的上级已获得移民局批准入境，但该女子是该高级官员的私人助理，被拒绝入境，并据称被告知她的旅行证件存在不符之处。

;

;马来西亚的腐败评级停滞不前，许多被指控的领导人仍在掌权

;

;Tiong 说，车站官员给马来西亚总领事馆打电话。马来西亚人在广州，看到她的同事遇险后寻求帮助。

;

;“我接到总领事馆工作人员的电话，讲述了据称发生的事情。

;

;“我联系了马来西亚人反贪污委员会（MACC）及其官员于下午3点前往吉隆坡国际机场进行调查。我会见了游客和值班的移民官员，并与他们进行了交谈。”他说。

;

;Tiong 说，移民官员告诉他存在语言障碍，这是他们和中国妇女之间的误会。 .

;

;他说，这些据信年龄在 40 多岁的女性的手机也被移民官员没收了。

;

;“他们有什么权力没收手机？这是他们第一次去马来西亚。这两位女士告诉我，她们在其他国家从未遇到过此类问题。

;

;“她们对这起事件感到震惊，这让她们感到非常尴尬。

;

;“她们记录了所有的情况。 ”他补充道。

;

;他说，在他的干预下，这名私人助理后来被允许进入该国。

; >;

;Tiong表示，他得知该电视台官员来到马来西亚，在莎阿南当地一所大学攻读博士学位，她的私人助理也陪同她。

;

;Tiong表示，这不是电视台的官员他第一次出现在吉隆坡国际机场解决此类问题。

;

;“周四的事件是我第五次去干预此类问题。

;

;“此外，声称我确实这样做了“没有通行证进入抵达区是不真实的，因为我有通行证，有效期到明年，”他说。

;

;Tiong 说，如果中国游客存在语言障碍，移民局应该聘请马来西亚机场控股有限公司雇用的翻译人员。

;

;他说他很困惑为什么移民局没有聘请翻译人员，尽管他们之前曾被建议这样做。

;

;可以马来西亚最新反腐行动对安瓦尔政府适得其反？

;

;据新闻门户网站周四晚报道，一名部长“闯入”吉隆坡国际机场到达大厅并制造骚乱，试图“释放”一名被禁止入境的中国公民。

;

;该新闻网站还声称，部长在没有许可证或通行证的情况下进入了机场的禁区。

;

;同时，移民局局长鲁斯林·朱索 (Ruslin Jusoh) 将军表示，已针对一名部长在吉隆坡国际机场制造骚乱的新闻报道展开调查。

;

;“将针对与该事件相关的所有方面进行彻底调查，”他说。

;

;警察枪杀一名青少年后，法国各地持续数天的暴力抗议活动已经开始影响了该国的旅游业，酒店和餐馆面临取消预订，一些酒店和餐馆也在骚乱中遭受了损失。

;

;自从 17 岁的纳赫尔周二在巴黎郊区的一个交通堵塞中死亡以来，酒店和餐饮业雇主主要协会主席蒂埃里·马克思 (Thierry Marx) 表示：“在所有受破坏和冲突影响的地区，我们的酒店会员都遭遇了一波取消预订的浪潮。”马克思说。周五，他收到了来自行业专业人士的每日警报，他们的企业遭受了“袭击、抢劫和破坏，包括一些餐馆和咖啡馆”。

;

;“我们的场所本质上是接待场所，有时甚至是避难所和危机情况下的帮助场所。他们绝不能承受自己没有激起的愤怒的后果，我们谴责这些行为。”他补充道。

;

;法国骚乱：青少年被杀如何将愤怒集中在警察策略上

;

;马克思希望当局“尽一切努力”保证世界上最受欢迎的旅游目的地酒店和餐饮业人员的安全。

;

;法国零售联合会 (FCD) 还呼吁加强商店周围的警察安全董事总经理雅克·克雷塞尔 (Jacques Creyssel) 表示。

;

;他表示，骚乱“引发了真实的抢劫场面”，“一百多家大中型食品或非食品商店遭到破坏、抢劫甚至焚烧” ”。

;

;克雷塞尔表示，这些事件“极其严重，成本极其高昂”，他表示已要求经济、内政和贸易部长采取行动。

;

;巴黎法兰西岛商会表示，正在确保动员其团队为受影响公司的贸易商和经理“提供必要的支持和技术援助，特别是在持续运营、保险赔偿等方面……”。;

;法国独立酒店和餐馆的 GHR 组织表示遗憾，“外国[电视网络]开始播放巴黎火与血的图像，这与现实不符”。

;

; “暴力和骚乱会持续下去并引发真正的取消浪潮吗？这就是风险。”总经理 Franck Trouet 说道。

;

;“亚洲游客，尤其是非常担心安全的游客，可能会毫不犹豫地推迟或取消行程，”他警告说。

;

;Protourisme 公司董事总经理迪迪埃·阿里诺 (Didier Arino) 表示：“熟悉我们的游客，例如比利时人或英国人，他们自己在郊区也遇到了问题，将能够理解这些事情。”

;

;但最后，他说“这就像我们在为目的地法国进行一场价值数千万欧元的负面宣传活动”。

;

;烟草商联合会也对这一行为感到愤慨。 “在最后几天的冲突中，商店遭到抢劫和洗劫，其中包括 91 家烟草商”。

;

;“如果这种情况继续下去，可能会使奥运会的组织工作变得非常复杂，特别是因为奥运会的大部分时间都在巴黎旅游局局长让-弗朗索瓦·里亚尔 (Jean-Francois Rial) 表示，活动将在塞纳-圣但尼地区举行，这是巴黎北部的一个贫困地区。

;中国的一对不和夫妇在相互指控后被送进了精神病院非法监禁震惊了大陆社交媒体。

;

;媒体报道称，妻子曲燕和丈夫袁强都来自中国北部的山西省，去年分别在护理机构度过了短暂的一段时间。据鼎鼎新闻报道，今年和今年都已被释放。

;

;袁告诉鼎鼎新闻，“她把我关在精神卫生医院80天”。

;

;袁与曲共同拥有一家公司的他声称，让他做出承诺是他妻子精心策划的一部分。他说，2021年他们开始经常打架后，曲经常告诉他，他情绪不稳定，需要精神治疗。

;

;尽管他们有分歧，袁表示他信任曲，并去了当地多家医院并获得了治疗。多份医疗证明显示他被诊断出患有临床抑郁症。

;

;袁说，2022年10月10日下午，事情急剧升级，当他离开办公室时，五名男子抓住他，把他拖进一辆汽车并把他带到西安市精神卫生中心，在那里他被强行穿上病号服，强行投入监狱。

;

;“一个小时后，我在病房里看到了我的妻子，我突然明白了，这是这是她的计划。”袁说。

;

;在接下来的80天里，袁被迫接受治疗，除了瞿和她的朋友之外，不准见任何人。今年年初，袁某出院，并出具了无精神病证明。

;

;二月份，曲某以与袁某类似的方式被送进精神病院。

;< p>;袁通过向医院播放妻子砸东西的视频，让医院相信他的妻子患有精神疾病，导致她被诊断为精神分裂症。

;

;曲案发三天后，她的家人找到了她

;

;出院后，她试图向警方报案，称袁某是为了报复而冤枉了她，但警方称证据不足。

;

;当地卫生健康委员会在调查案件时发现，两家精神卫生医院在诊断和收治精神病患者方面没有违反任何法律要求。

;

;新闻报道确实如此没有提及此后袁或瞿是否采取了任何进一步的法律行动。

;

;这个故事在社交媒体上引发了关于心理健康和人际关系的讨论。

;

;有人说： “天哪，这真是一个可怕的故事。”

;

;还有人问道：“如果我被送到精神卫生医院，我如何证明我没有精神疾病？”

;

; p>;

;有关夫妻不和的故事经常在大陆社交媒体上流行。

;

;今年四月，上海一名男子批评他的妻子向一家餐馆抱怨食物质量差，引起了中国的愤怒。一顿面条，并在事后拍摄了她打架的过程，他声称这表明她情绪崩溃。

;韩国领导人向“杀手”考试问题和课后补习宣战活动人士表示，只有政府设法缓解青少年进入优质大学所面临的激烈竞争，任何教育改革才会有效。

;

;官员们最近几周严厉打击了课外学习场所，或者hagwon，并在主要中心进行了税务突击搜查，学生们可以在这些中心呆到几乎午夜，以复习最重要的大学入学考试。

;

;在本月早些时候，韩国总统尹锡烈痛斥将在臭名昭著的 SAT 考试（称为 Suneung）中，他提出了“杀手级问题”，他告诉教育部长李柱浩，学生们接受官方课程中甚至没有涵盖的具有挑战性主题的测试是“极其不公平和不公正的”。

;

;“看到这一点，人们可能会认为教育当局和私人补习行业是同谋，”尹说，他指责教育当局和私人教育部门像“卡特尔”一样有效地运作。

;

;为什么南方韩国人陷入终身学习的困境

;

;此后，教育部上周推出了一个在线平台，举报与补习相关的违规行为，包括补习班夸张的广告、虚高的补习费用以及涉嫌隐瞒的补习费用。

;

;根据首尔市教育局 2021 年的一份报告，超过 100 所首尔学校被发现发布虚假或误导性广告，随后收到官方警告或罚款。

;

; p>;

;税务机关还突击搜查了该国三大补习学校，包括最大的 Megastudy，进行未经宣布的税务调查，同时青瓦台警告称，将对任何涉嫌逃税和其他违规行为的学园进行法律处罚。

;< Megastudy 去年的年销售额增长了 19%，达到 8,360 亿韩元（6.35 亿美元），营业利润飙升 36%，达到 1,340 亿韩元。 2022 年，韩国各地约有 85,000 名学园。

;

;其负责人 Son Ju-eun 周二驳回了有关韩国私人补习行业、公共教育当局和 SAT 考试当局“串通”的指控。从致命问题中获利。

;

;致命问题从 2008 年开始出现在考试中。

;

;那时，私人辅导行业仅“作为对 SAT 变化的回应”而蓬勃发展，包括孙正义在 KBS 新闻脱口秀节目中表示，这是致命的问题。

;

;孙正义表示，韩国的私人补习市场去年价值 22 万亿韩元（167 亿美元），约占该国 GDP 总量的 1% – 由于韩国的出生率是世界上最低的，出生率很快就会呈螺旋式下降，从 2016 年的 40 万左右下降到去年的 29 万。

;

;尹对致命问题的攻击让许多学生和家长感到不安，因为他们距离 11 月至关重要的年度考试仅几个月。

;

;“距离 Suneung 仅五个月，我感觉自己被闪电击中了”，首尔 Hangaram 高中的 18 岁女孩必须坐在座位上告诉在线新闻媒体 MoneyS。

;

;“这让我感到惊讶，因为我花了数千美元为我的孩子提供私人辅导，让他为所谓的杀手级问题做好准备。”一位名叫 Park 的 62 岁父亲说道，他的儿子正在准备今年的考试，希望能进入医学院。

;

;一位自称张的私人数学导师表示，消除凶手”问题对于那些擅长解决挑战性问题的前1%的学生来说是一个打击。”

;

;“现在，在Suneung中只要犯一个错误就可以将你从顶级推到第三级，而改变你的整个人生轨迹，因为会有很多学生获得近乎完美的分数。”他说。

;

;另一位参加第二次考试的学生的父亲表示，要求只要韩国目前对学生进入大学的强化评估保持不变，私人辅导就会继续存在。

;

;“在这种情况下，认为消除致命问题后辅导就会消失是荒谬的，”他说。

;

;支持改革的活动人士表示，虽然尹的命令是韩国使 SAT 考试更加公平并缓解对私人辅导需求的机会，但还需要做更多的事情。

;

;韩国29 岁女性“因为孤独而进入美国高中”

;

;“从长远来看……该国由高度分层的学校组成的教育体系必须得到纠正，因为私人补习助长了入学的过度竞争倡导教育改革的公民运动 Noworry 的政策总监申素英 (Shin So-young) 说道。

;

;公民组织“无需担心私立教育的世界”的积极分子申素英 (Shin So-young) 表示，计划中的变化可能不足以遏制竞争。

;

;“政府需要制定更广泛的计划，解决如何缓解过度竞争以进入一些最好的大学的问题申说。

;

;Chamhakbumo 教育改革运动的领导人 Gang Hye-seung 表示，当局应重点关注“为教育机会创造公平的竞争环境，而不是触及表面”，采取消除致命问题等举措.

;

;“没有证据表明平等教育阻碍国家发展，”她说。

;

;联合报告显示，近十分之八的学生使用补习班等私立教育产品教育部和政府统计局的数据显示。

;

;去年的一份报告显示，对私立教育的严重依赖导致韩国养育孩子的成本位居全球最高。

;

;2022 年的政府数据显示，平均月收入 800 万韩元（6,100 美元）或以上的家庭平均每月花费 648,000 韩元让中学生在学校接受平均每周 9.4 小时的课程.

;

;自1980年时任军事独裁者全斗焕全面禁止私人补习以来，韩国多次打击私人补习。

;

;然而，由于家长的原因，这些努力都以失败告终。不断想方设法规避法律法规，因为在这个竞争激烈的社会，最好的学校往往意味着找到好工作的最佳机会和最好的婚姻前景。

;

;香港科技主管首次透露，政府试图禁止互联网搜索巨头谷歌不愿在未经法院命令的情况下删除相关内容，引发了这首通过禁令流行的抗议歌曲。

;

;创新、科技和工业部部长孙东周六指责这家美国公司试图”批评者对言论自由以及此举是否会导致谷歌退出香港表示担忧。

;

;“愿荣光归香港”抗议歌曲将被禁止？政府向法院提交禁令

;

;拟议的禁令是在几项海外体育赛事的组织者错误地演奏了抗议曲子而不是中国国歌《义勇军进行曲》之后提出的。大多数错误源于 Google 上“香港国歌”的热门搜索结果。

;

;当地政府已要求 Google 禁止这首歌出现在其搜索中，但无济于事。

;

;Sun 回忆起与这家科技巨头的谈判，期间官员们多次要求删除“错误信息”。

;

;“谷歌没有采纳我们的建议，而是说：‘你必须证明它违反了当地法律并提交法庭命令，”孙周六告诉 NowTV。 “好吧，既然你提出了法律问题，我们就用法律手段来解决问题。这就是我们申请禁令的原因。”

;

; Sat, 01 Jul 2023 13:50:02 +0800 Why is Malaysia’s ringgit in a slump and will it affect PM Anwar’s coalition in this year’s state polls?https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/explained/article/3226109/why-malaysias-ringgit-slump-and-will-it-affect-pm-anwars-coalition-years-state-polls?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.01 13:45;
;;

;The Malaysian ringgit has endured a torrid year on foreign exchange markets, as the export-focused economy contends with the aftershocks of steep interest-rate increases in the United States, and the slower-than-expected return of top trading partner China from its long self-isolation during the pandemic.

;

;The currency has been Southeast Asia's worst performer so far this year. It hit a seven-month low on Friday last week, ending the week at 4.672 to the US dollar, according to a Reuters report.

;

;It rebounded slightly this week after the central bank said it would intervene to restrict “excessive” currency movements, adding that the ringgit's value did not reflect the country's economic fundamentals.

;

;On Wednesday, the ringgit closed at 4.669 against the US dollar, according to Reuters data.

;

;Malaysia's central bank to step in to stabilise ringgit amid 'excessive' losses

;

;But the central bank's confidence in the ringgit is not shared by a public who had emptied out their savings to survive the pandemic, only to emerge into a cost-of-living crisis and find that their money buys them less than it did.

;

;Exporters and tourism players stand to benefit from the weak ringgit, experts say, with foreign clients and tourists more inclined to leverage their stronger currencies. Locals, meanwhile, end up having to hold back as the prices of everything, from their favourite imported biscuits to cosmetics and even fresh chickens, have gone up.

;

;With just weeks to go before Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's administration faces its first real test in state elections, the ringgit's weakness may also take on a political dimension.

;

;

;

;The ringgit's weakness stems from pressures that are beyond the control of either the government or the central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM), experts say, as portfolio investors keep their distance from emerging markets amid the US Federal Reserve's rate increases and China's slow recovery.

;

;Demand from China – Malaysia's largest trading partner – has been muted at best over the first five months of this year, with the vast majority of sectors posting annual declines in shipments.

;

;“While Malaysia is not alone in experiencing sizeable currency depreciation against the US dollar, its steeper decline versus its Asean peers could be attributed to its higher exposure to the Chinese economy and renminbi movements,” said Yeah Kim Leng, an economics professor at Malaysia's Sunway University.

;

;'Demand is high': Singaporeans eye cheaper trips to Malaysia as ringgit plunges

;

;The US dollar's strength, which has largely been attributed to the Fed's aggressive efforts to contain inflation, also ended up triggering a panic among developed economies rushing to avoid falling into stagflation – where stagnating growth meets soaring inflation.

;

;This soured the mood among consumers in many Western economies, which are key markets for electronics exports from Malaysia and other Southeast Asian nations.

;

;The ringgit is also vulnerable to being dragged down by easing global commodity prices, with commodity exports such as palm oil, sweet crude and natural gas accounting for a sizeable chunk of Malaysia's shipments.

;

;Economists say Malaysia has done what is necessary to shore up its economy while holding down inflation – a primary target of the central bank when it decides to raise its benchmark interest rate.

;

;Yet watchful investors “have adopted a 'wait-and-see' attitude … resulting in weaker ringgit demand”, Yeah said.

;

;

;

;On the ground, Malaysian consumers – especially those in the middle class – have had to make increasingly hard decisions when they shop, as the weak ringgit means costlier goods.

;

;For A. Raman, eating healthily has always come at a premium, but he now has to spend even more time searching for cheaper alternatives to the gourmet cheeses and other ingredients that make his daily salads more palatable.

;

;“I've stopped buying imported foods because they're just too expensive now,” the IT professional said. “I've Googled for more recipes that use cheaper ingredients that can be found locally.”

;

;But the weak currency also presents a path towards potentially higher revenue for some sectors.

;

;Last week, the Malaysian Association of Hotel Owners (Maho) suggested that they be allowed to charge foreigners in US dollars, to boost their revenues as they deal with slow post-pandemic recovery and higher costs from a government-mandated minimum wage and higher electricity tariffs.

;

;“Hotels should now do something to get better revenue and increase yield since the cost of doing business … has gone very high. Occupancy has not improved much either, around 45-55 per cent,” Maho president Teo Chiang Hong was quoted as saying by local English newspaper the New Straits Times.

;

;

;

;Previous periods of ringgit weakness had broadly provided a boon for exports as destination countries bought more Malaysian products on the cheap.

;

;“Exporters benefit most from a depreciation as well as other corporations holding foreign currency,” Geoffrey Williams, an economist with the Malaysia University of Science and Technology, told This Week in Asia.

;

;But that may not be the case this time, as key Western markets increased interest rates to fight their own inflation crises, squashing demand for Malaysian shipments of semiconductor components and other electronic goods.

;

;Local technology players in the semiconductor and consumer electronics sectors have suffered over the first quarter of this year, with Western demand soft and China's much-trailed reopening failing to lead to an explosion of Southeast Asian exports.

;

;

;

;The last time BNM intervened in the market, it banned offshore trade of the ringgit in the aftermath of Donald Trump's shock win in the 2016 US presidential election, which triggered a global sell-off in emerging markets.

;

;The move sparked a revolt among foreign portfolio investors, though they eventually returned as the central bank improved its onshore trading facilities.

;

;Malaysia's PM Anwar faces first 'worrisome' test as state polls loom

;

;This time there was not much policy space – or reason – for BNM to be as aggressive in its response, as it lacked sufficient foreign currency reserves to meaningfully influence the ringgit, while a steep increase to its key policy rate would have limited effect on the ringgit and “crush” borrowers, Williams said.

;

;“So maintaining an independent policy stance, keeping to its mandate and promoting fundamentals is the best option for BNM,” he said.

;

;“Encouraging firms to buy ringgit with their foreign currency reserves will also help in the short term as a market-driven response.”

;

;In the quest for stability, there have been rumblings of a return to a ringgit peg to the US dollar.

;

;But Deputy Finance Minister Ahmad Maslan dismissed the idea, saying it would undo whatever progress gained from the increases to BNM's key rate and restrict capital flows.

;

;Sunway University's Yeah agreed, saying: “The most compelling reason for not resorting to a currency peg is that the country is not experiencing an economic or financial crisis.”

;

;

;

;The opposition Perikatan Nasional bloc has demanded that heads must roll over what it had described as the government's failure to manage the economy.

;

;“The opposition's narrative is more on the government failing to deliver what it has promised or advocated to deliver when it was in opposition,” said Hafidzi Razali, an associate director with government affairs and public policy consulting firm BowerGroupAsia.

;

;But as Anwar's coalition faces six looming state polls, currency woes may be the least of his problems.

;

;“[The ringgit weakness] will be a point of ridicule, but not a major factor to swing voters,” Razali said. “It will be linked to the cost of living, as that is more relatable to the masses.”

;A week after an abortive uprising by a mercenary chief shook his authority, Vladimir Putin's efforts to reassert his control are showing cracks.

;

;Infighting spread within the security establishment as the Russian president moved on senior players thought to have supported the 24-hour mutiny by Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin. One top general was detained for questioning, according to people familiar with the moves.

;

;Opponents of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu from the security services stepped up internal calls for his removal, they said, speaking on condition of anonymity to describe events that aren't public.

;

;Prigozhin had been publicly attacking Shoigu, a long-time ally of Putin's, for months over the lack of success in the invasion of Ukraine. Putin spent the week trying to reassure key constituencies, with televised public events involving military, business and other groups. While polls showed his public support remained strong, doubts about his control among the government and business elite spread, insiders said.

;

;Where are Russia's top generals? Rumours swirl after Wagner mutiny

;

;The continuing turmoil deepened questions about what Prigozhin's dramatic march on Moscow a week ago would mean for Putin's 17-month-old invasion of Ukraine. The government in Kyiv renewed calls for more help for its military. There were growing signs that the US and some of its allies were reconsidering earlier caution on sending new kinds of weapons, despite fears about how the shaken Russian president might react.

;

;“It's clear that Putin comes out of this crisis weakened,” EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said on Thursday. “But a weaker Putin is a greater danger.”

;

;While Western officials agreed that Putin's authority had been eroded by the events, some suggested his undermined position will make him less likely to escalate the war. Ukraine's allies were pushing for stronger assurances for the country's possible membership in Nato at the alliance's summit next month.

;

;US and European officials were watching closely for any indication the turmoil might affect Russia's vast nuclear arsenal but said so far, there's no sign of any increased risk. Many capitals have grown jaded to the Kremlin's repeated threats to use the arms in the war against Ukraine, officials said.

;

;“In the US, they view this mutiny as a kind of victory – the war in Ukraine has shown cracks in Putin's rule,” said Livia Paggi, managing director and head of political risk at consultancy JS Held. “What isn't fully understood is what kind of chaos would follow if it were actually to happen,” she said, referring to the possibility of regime change.

;

;In Russia, investigators questioned Sergei Surovikin, a prominent general who oversaw the invading forces from October to January, over the events, according to a person familiar with the situation. Known as “General Armageddon” for his ruthless fighting in Syria, Surovikin isn't in custody but his movements are restricted, the person said. He couldn't be reached for comment.

;

;CNN reported on Thursday, citing documents from the Dossier Centre, which investigates the Russian leadership, that the general had a personal registration with Wagner.

;

;“A massive investigation has begun,” said Sergei Markov, a political analyst with close Kremlin ties. “All the generals and officers who were in contact with Prigozhin and Wagner will be questioned.”

;

;As Russia teetered, the elite trembled, and some private jets left

;

;Broader probes were also under way into close allies of Shoigu, the defence minister, according to a person familiar with the situation. There has been no public confirmation of that or of Surovikin's whereabouts.

;

;One insider described what he called a power vacuum in the wake of the uprising that has undermined Putin proteges like Shoigu.

;

;But Western-allied officials said they don't expect an imminent shake-up that would threaten the positions of Shoigu and Russia's military chief, General Valery Gerasimov. Known for his loyalty, Putin is especially reluctant to remove long-time supporters under pressure.

;

;“The loss of face for all the players involved hasn't been overcome,” said Mikhail Vinogradov, head of the St. Petersburg Politics Foundation. “About repressions among security forces there is absolutely no clarity, but no one is in a hurry to refute them.”

;

;Putin chose to spotlight the military in his first public appearance after the weekend revolt ended. On Tuesday, he addressed 2,500 troops on the main square inside the Kremlin and later met with uniformed officers in an ornate hall to thank them for their loyalty.

;

;On a stop in Dagestan the next day, Putin waded into a crowd of adoring supporters, something he's rarely done since the Covid-19 pandemic.

;

;Putin struck a positive note at a business forum on Thursday. “There's a feeling of confidence that no matter what difficulties arise, we will overcome them all calmly, rhythmically, and moving forward,” he said, after a standing ovation from the invited guests on his arrival.

;

;A new opinion poll showed support for the president has held steady despite the mutiny. At the same time, the survey showed a majority of Russians now support peace talks to end the war in Ukraine instead of continuing the military operation.

;

;Among the elite, the abortive uprising by a long-time protégé has fuelled doubts about Putin's control, but he's bound top government and business leaders to him with the international isolation wrought by his war. Many of them are subject to US and European sanctions.

;

;“The most likely scenario is not a direct challenge to Putin as leader, but the continuing decay of the ruling system,” said Oksana Antonenko, a global fellow at the Kennan Institute. With his current term set to end next year, “it's still his choice whether to stay post-2024 but the arguments are stronger for him to step down than before.”

;At least 25 people were killed and eight others injured after a bus caught fire overnight on an expressway in western India on Saturday, police said.

;

;The bus was travelling to the city of Pune when it hit a pole and overturned after midnight, causing its diesel tank to catch fire, senior police officer Baburao Mahamuni said.

;

;“There were about 30-35 people in the bus. Twenty-five people have died and eight others are injured,” he said.

;

;The injured, including the bus driver, have been admitted to a hospital near the site of the crash in Maharashtra state, about 400km east of India's financial capital Mumbai.

;

;Police said they had launched an inquiry into the crash.

;

;“The priority at this moment is to identify the bodies and hand them over to their family members,” local media quoted police superintendent Sunil Kadasane as saying.

;

;India's train disaster shows chronic lack of investment in rail safety: experts

;

;Images showed the bus engulfed in flames and later the charred remains of the vehicle overturned on the highway.

;

;Three children were among the dead, a police officer told reporters.

;

;“Deeply saddened by the devastating bus mishap in Buldhana,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi said on Twitter.

;

;“My thoughts and prayers are with the families of those who lost their lives. May the injured recover soon.”

;

;Maharashtra Chief Minister Eknath Shinde said he felt “deep grief” over the accident and pledged compensation of 500,000 rupees (US$6,100) to the families of those killed.

;

;Accidents are common on India's vast network of roads, which are poorly maintained and notoriously dangerous.

;

;The main causes are excessive speed, not wearing helmets – sales of two-wheelers far outstrip those of cars – and not using seat belts.

;

;India accounts for 11 per cent of the global road death toll despite having just one per cent of the world's vehicles, according to a World Bank report released in 2021.

;

;The same report estimated 150,000 car crash fatalities in India annually, or one person every four minutes.

;

;

;It added that road crashes cost the Indian economy around US$75 billion each year, with medical expenses and loss of income driving many accident survivors into poverty.

;

;In May, at least 21 people died when a bus veered off a bridge in India, reportedly after the driver fell asleep at the wheel.

;

;And last October, at least 31 people were killed after a bus carrying wedding guests veered off the road and fell into a deep gorge in northern India.
